etymology.description: 或(maybe; some) + 者(one; person/thing) = originally 'some (people/things)', later used as 'or; perhaps'.
etymology.interpretation: Built from a classical noun phrase meaning 'some ones', it generalized to mark alternatives and uncertainty; in modern Mandarin it links options in statements (vs. 还是 in questions) and can also mean 'perhaps'.

examples.chinese: 我们明天或者后天去北京(我們明天或者後天去北京)。
examples.pinyin: Wǒmen míngtiān huòzhě hòutiān qù Běijīng.
examples.english: We’ll go to Beijing tomorrow or the day after tomorrow.

examples.chinese: 他现在很忙(他現在很忙)，或者改天再谈吧(或者改天再談吧)。
examples.pinyin: Tā xiànzài hěn máng, huòzhě gǎitiān zài tán ba.
examples.english: He’s busy now; maybe we can talk another day.

examples.chinese: 你可以坐地铁或者打车去机场(你可以坐地鐵或者打車去機場)。
examples.pinyin: Nǐ kěyǐ zuò dìtiě huòzhě dǎ chē qù jīchǎng.
examples.english: You can take the subway or a taxi to the airport.
